t.x: Cooked rice, the staple food of Korea. Also used to mean 'meal' in general. '밥 먹었어?' (Did you eat?) is a common greeting.
e: Have you eaten?
Shall we have rice for lunch today?
In Korea, "bap" means not just rice but the entire meal.
"Have you eaten?" as a greeting shows the social significance of food in Korean culture.

t.x: Traditional Korean fermented vegetable dish, usually made with napa cabbage and radish. A staple side dish in Korean cuisine.
e: Do you like kimchi?
My grandmother made this kimchi herself.
Kimchi is registered as a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage.
Kimjang culture embodies the Korean spirit of community and seasonal wisdom.

t.x: The most basic drink. Essential vocabulary for ordering at restaurants.
e: Water, please.
Water is free at Korean restaurants.
It's healthy to drink water slowly during meals.
In Korea, offering water to guests first is a basic courtesy.

t.x: Edible animal flesh. Includes beef, pork, chicken, etc. In Korea, grilled meat dishes like samgyeopsal and galbi are popular.
e: Want to go eat some meat?
Koreans love to grill and eat meat.
The combination of samgyeopsal and soju is a symbol of Korean dining culture.
The culture of grilling meat together reflects the Korean spirit of sharing.

t.x: Korean-style instant noodles. Popular as a late-night snack or quick meal because it's fast and easy to make.
e: Shall I make you some ramyeon?
Rainy days make me crave ramyeon.
In Korea, you can cook and eat ramyeon right at convenience stores.
"Want to come up for ramyeon?" became a famous expression from Korean dramas.

t.x: When food tastes good. One of the most commonly used expressions when eating.
e: This is really delicious!
The food I had yesterday was so good.
"Masitda" can express not just taste but also a great experience.
In Korean, "delicious" goes beyond taste to express admiration and satisfaction.

t.x: Having a hot, pungent taste. A common flavor in Korean cuisine.
e: Is this spicy?
Most Korean food tends to be spicy.
If you can't handle spicy food, say "Please make it not spicy."
Koreans' preference for spicy food developed after chili peppers were introduced.

t.x: A place that sells food. A more general and casual expression than 'restaurant'.
e: Where is the restaurant?
There is a good restaurant nearby.
In Korean restaurants, side dishes are provided for free.
Korean restaurant culture is characterized by free side dish refills and communal dining.

t.x: The state of feeling hungry. Used when you want to eat food.
e: I'm hungry.
I'm so hungry because I didn't eat lunch.
"Hungry" is often used when suggesting mealtime.
In Korea, saying "I'm hungry" can be understood as an invitation to eat together.

t.x: A beverage made from coffee beans. Very popular in Korea, with coffee shops everywhere.
e: Do you want some coffee?
Korea is one of the countries that drinks the most coffee.
Cafe culture is so developed that Seoul has countless cafes.
Korean cafe culture has evolved into spaces for work, rest, and social meetings.

t.x: A traditional Korean dish of rice topped with vegetables and gochujang, mixed together before eating.
e: Have you tried bibimbap?
Bibimbap is eaten by mixing various ingredients together.
Jeonju bibimbap is a representative local dish of North Jeolla Province.
The diverse ingredients in bibimbap embody the Korean aesthetic of harmony and balance.

t.x: Traditional Korean dish of marinated and grilled beef.
e: Do you like bulgogi?
Bulgogi is characterized by its sweet taste.
Bulgogi is one of the most popular Korean dishes among foreigners.
Bulgogi's sweet and savory marinade showcases the essence of Korean cuisine.

t.x: Pork belly. One of the most popular meat dishes in Korea.
e: Want to go eat samgyeopsal?
Samgyeopsal is eaten wrapped in lettuce.
Samgyeopsal is a popular menu for Korean office dinners.
The culture of grilling samgyeopsal together plays an important role in Korean bonding.

t.x: Rice and various ingredients rolled in seaweed. Popular as a lunch box or snack.
e: Do you want some kimbap?
We bring kimbap for picnics.
There are various types like tuna kimbap and cheese kimbap.
Unlike Japanese sushi, kimbap is characterized by seasoning rice with sesame oil and salt.

t.x: Rice cakes stir-fried in spicy gochujang sauce. A representative Korean street food.
e: Do you like tteokbokki?
Tteokbokki has a sweet and spicy taste.
Tteokbokki and fried food combo is popular at bunsik restaurants.
Tteokbokki has a history of starting as royal cuisine and developing into a commoner food.

t.x: Korean-style stew with broth. Includes kimchi jjigae, doenjang jjigae, etc.
e: Do you want some stew?
Hot stew is the best on cold days.
Doenjang jjigae and kimchi jjigae are representative Korean home meals.
Sharing stew from one pot reflects Korean community culture.

t.x: Traditional Korean dish of stir-fried glass noodles and vegetables. Often eaten during holidays.
e: Do you like japchae?
Japchae is often eaten during holidays.
Japchae is made by stir-frying various vegetables with glass noodles.
Japchae was originally a royal court dish but is now a popular holiday food.

t.x: Beef or pork ribs. Marinated and grilled or braised.
e: Do you like galbi?
Galbi has a sweet and delicious marinade.
LA galbi is a style developed by Korean Americans.
Galbi is a special food that never misses Korean holidays and celebrations.

t.x: Cold noodle dish served in chilled broth or spicy sauce. Popular in summer.
e: Have you tried naengmyeon?
Cold noodles are the best in hot summer.
Pyongyang naengmyeon and Hamheung naengmyeon have different tastes and styles.
Naengmyeon was originally a North Korean dish but is now loved in South Korea too.

t.x: Chicken soup with ginseng. Famous as a summer health food.
e: Have you tried samgyetang?
Eating samgyetang in summer helps restore energy.
There's a tradition of eating samgyetang on the hottest days.
With the wisdom of "fight fire with fire," Koreans eat hot samgyetang on hot days.

t.x: Korean-style sausage made with intestines filled with glass noodles and vegetables.
e: Do you like sundae?
Sundae tastes good when eaten with tteokbokki.
There are different types of sundae by region like baek-sundae and pi-sundae.
Sundae has a long history as a representative Korean snack and drinking food.

t.x: Traditional Korean food made by coating ingredients in flour and egg, then pan-frying.
e: Have you tried jeon?
Rainy days make you crave jeon.
Various jeon are made and eaten during holidays.
"Pajeon with makgeolli on rainy days" is an expression that captures Korean sentiment.

t.x: Dumplings made with flour dough filled with meat and vegetables. Steamed, pan-fried, or deep-fried.
e: Have you tried mandu?
Which do you prefer, kimchi mandu or meat mandu?
In Korea, there's a tradition of eating mandu soup on New Year's Day.
Mandu originated from China and developed uniquely in Korea.

t.x: Traditional Korean fermented soybean paste. Used in stews and soups.
e: Do you know doenjang?
Doenjang jjigae is a staple of Korean home cooking.
Homemade doenjang has a deeper flavor.
Doenjang is a traditional fermented paste that represents Korean fermentation culture.

t.x: Spicy Korean traditional paste made with chili powder. Used in bibimbap, tteokbokki, etc.
e: Is gochujang spicy?
We mix bibimbap with gochujang.
Gochujang is the seasoning responsible for the spiciness in Korean food.
Gochujang is a unique Korean fermented paste developed after chili peppers were introduced.

t.x: Main vegetable ingredient for kimchi. Widely used during kimjang season.
e: Do you eat napa cabbage?
Napa cabbage kimchi is the most representative Korean kimchi.
Families gather to make napa cabbage kimchi during kimjang season.
Napa cabbage holds an important position as the main ingredient for kimchi in Korean food culture.

t.x: Chicken egg. A basic ingredient used in various dishes.
e: Do you eat eggs?
Rolled omelette is popular as a lunchbox side dish.
In Korea, people eat sauna eggs at jjimjilbang.
Eggs are one of the most versatile ingredients in Korean home cooking.

t.x: Food made from soybeans. Cooked in various ways like stew and pan-frying.
e: Do you like tofu?
Soft tofu stew is a popular Korean dish.
Tofu is a high-protein, low-calorie food that is good for health.
Tofu is a key ingredient in Korean temple food and healthy cuisine.

t.x: Various small dishes eaten with rice. A characteristic of Korean meals.
e: More side dishes, please.
In Korean restaurants, side dishes are refilled for free.
It's convenient to prepare side dishes at home in advance.
Banchan culture shows the diversity and nutritional balance of the Korean table.

t.x: Korean-style clear soup. A basic dish eaten with rice.
e: Do you like soup?
Soup is always served with Korean meals.
There is a tradition of eating seaweed soup on birthdays.
"Soup culture" is one of the core characteristics of Korean dining.

t.x: Side dishes of blanched or stir-fried seasoned vegetables. Also used in bibimbap.
e: Do you eat namul?
Bibimbap contains various namul.
There are spinach namul, bean sprout namul, fernbrake namul, etc.
Namul dishes are the foundation of Korean vegetarian culture and healthy eating.

t.x: Korea's representative alcoholic beverage. Clear and high in alcohol content.
e: Do you drink soju?
Soju is a representative Korean alcohol.
Fruit-flavored soju is also popular these days.
Soju is the national drink at the center of Korean drinking culture.

t.x: Alcoholic beverage made from barley. Popular to drink with chicken.
e: Do you want some beer?
Chicken and beer is a popular combination in Korea.
The craft beer market is growing rapidly in Korea.
"Chimaek" has become a word representing Korea's unique drinking culture.

t.x: Simple food made by shaping rice into balls with your fist.
e: Do you want some rice balls?
Rice balls are good for lunch boxes.
There are tuna rice balls, kimchi rice balls, etc.
Rice balls are a representative Korean snack that is both convenient and nutritious.

t.x: Rice mixed with barley. Popular as a healthy food.
e: Have you tried barley rice?
Barley rice is healthy.
Barley rice bibimbap is eaten with ssamjang.
Barley rice was once a staple for commoners and is now re-emerging as a health food.

t.x: Kimchi made from cubed radish. Goes well with seolleongtang.
e: Do you like kkakdugi?
Kkakdugi is kimchi made with radish.
Kkakdugi goes well with seolleongtang.
Kkakdugi is one of the representative Korean kimchis along with baechu kimchi.

t.x: Vegetable commonly used as a seasoning in Korean cooking.
e: Should I add green onion?
Pajeon is a popular food on rainy days.
Large green onions and small green onions have different uses.
Green onion is an essential vegetable used as seasoning and garnish in Korean cooking.

t.x: An essential seasoning in Korean cooking. Also good for health.
e: Do you like garlic?
Korean food uses a lot of garlic.
We grill garlic together when grilling samgyeopsal.
Korean garlic consumption is among the highest in the world, making it a key ingredient.

t.x: Green vegetable often eaten as namul. Also goes in bibimbap.
e: Do you eat spinach?
Seasoned spinach is a healthy side dish.
Adding spinach to doenjang soup makes it delicious.
Spinach is a representative vegetable that adds nutrition and flavor to Korean home cooking.

t.x: Vegetable often used in stews and pancakes in Korea.
e: Do you eat squash?
Squash pancake is nutty and sweet.
Making porridge with ripe squash is very nutritious.
Squash is used in various ways in Korea, from stuffed pancakes to porridge.

t.x: Vegetable that adds sweetness. Used in stir-fries, stews, etc.
e: Should I add onion?
Onion is a basic ingredient in Korean cooking.
Onions become sweet when cooked for a long time.
Onion is an essential ingredient used in almost all Korean home cooking.

t.x: Orange root vegetable. Used in various dishes.
e: Do you like carrots?
Carrots are often used in Korean side dishes.
Carrot rapé is a popular salad these days.
Carrots are an important ingredient for color and nutrition in Korean vegetable dishes.

t.x: A staple crop eaten worldwide. In Korea, used in gamjatang and potato pancakes.
e: Do you eat potatoes?
Gamjatang is a soup made with pork bones.
Potato pancake is a local food of Gangwon Province.
Potatoes were introduced in the late Joseon period and became deeply rooted in Korean food culture.

t.x: Sweet root vegetable. Popular as a winter snack.
e: Do you like sweet potatoes?
Roasted sweet potatoes are popular in winter.
Sweet potatoes taste good when eaten with kimchi.
Sweet potatoes started as a famine relief crop and are now a healthy modern snack.

t.x: Root used as a spice. Known to be good for colds.
e: Should I add ginger?
Ginger tea is good for colds.
Ginger is used to remove fishy smells in Korean cooking.
Ginger plays an important role as both a herbal ingredient and a spice in Korean cuisine.

t.x: Seeds that add nutty flavor. Sprinkled on namul or rice.
e: Do you like sesame seeds?
Sprinkling sesame on namul makes it nutty.
Black sesame porridge is made with black sesame seeds.
Sesame seeds are essential for adding garnish and nutty flavor to Korean dishes.

t.x: Oil made from sesame seeds. Essential ingredient for nutty flavor in Korean food.
e: I like the smell of sesame oil.
Bibimbap tastes better with sesame oil.
Sesame oil is often used as a finishing touch in Korean cooking.
Sesame oil is a key condiment that adds flavor and aroma to Korean cuisine.

t.x: Traditional Korean seasoning made from soybeans. Used to season dishes.
e: Do you have soy sauce?
It's delicious when dipped in soy sauce.
Traditional Korean soy sauce and Japanese-style soy sauce taste different.
Korean soy sauce culture is the essence of fermentation culture with thousands of years of history.

t.x: Sour seasoning. Often added to naengmyeon or raw fish.
e: Do you have vinegar?
We add vinegar to naengmyeon.
In Korea, persimmon vinegar and apple vinegar are popular.
Vinegar is the condiment responsible for sourness and tanginess in Korean food.

t.x: Basic seasoning for sweetness. Essential in cooking and baking.
e: Should I add sugar?
Sugar is used to add sweetness in Korean cooking.
Bulgogi marinade contains sugar.
The "sweet-salty" taste of Korean cuisine comes from the harmony of sugar and soy sauce.
